questions.text: Which of the following is not a classic feature of a salt-losing crisis in an infant with congenital adrenal hyperplasia?
questions.solution:
• In CAH, an enzyme deficiency in the steroid hormone synthesis pathway can lead to a combined cortisol and aldosterone insufficiency.
  • Aldosterone promotes water and sodium reabsorption in exchange for potassium by upregulating Na/K pump activity in the distal nephron. Its absence therefore results in a salt-losing crisis with hyponatremia, hyperkalemia (and associated metabolic acidosis), and hypotension. At the same time, the lack of cortisol causes hypoglycemia.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: An infant with congenital adrenal hyperplasia results in a salt-losing crisis with hyponatremia, hyperkalemia (and associated metabolic acidosis), and hypotension

questions.text: Most common cause of hyperthyroidism in children is?
questions.solution:
• The most common cause of hyperthyroidism is Grave's disease.
  • This is an autoimmune condition where antibodies (TSH receptor antibodies - TRAb) mimic TSH and activate the TSH-R on the thyroid gland, producing excessive thyroid hormone.
  • Other causes of hyperthyroidism include:
    • Toxic multinodular goitre
    • Toxic adenoma
    • Thyroid carcinoma
    • Neonatal hyperthyroidism - due to transplacental transfer of maternal TRAb to the fetus
    • hCG-secreting tumors - hCG has a similar structure to TSH and so can mimic it
    • Functioning pituitary adenoma leading to increased production of TSH

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The most common cause of hyperthyroidism is Grave's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most dreaded complication of late diagnosis of congenital hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
Congenital hypothyroidism (CH) is a condition present at birth where the thyroid gland fails to produce adequate thyroid hormones, crucial for growth, metabolism, and brain development in infants.

Clinical Features

  1. Newborn Features (often subtle):
    • Prolonged jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
    • Poor feeding
    • Lethargy or decreased activity
    • Hypotonia (reduced muscle tone or "floppiness")
    • Large fontanelles (soft spots on the head, especially the posterior fontanelle)
    • Constipation
  2. Physical Signs:
    • Puffy face with a broad nose
    • Macroglossia (enlarged tongue)
    • Cold, mottled skin
    • Umbilical hernia
    • Coarse or dry skin and hair
    • Enlarged abdomen
    • Hoarse cry
  3. Growth and Developmental Features (if untreated):
    • Growth retardation
    • Delayed skeletal maturation
    • Intellectual disability (mental retardation)
    • Developmental delays in motor skills, cognition, and language

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Late diagnosis and delayed treatment can lead to impaired neurocognitive development and growth.

The risk of neurocognitive complications is significantly reduced if early diagnosis and treatment is started within first two weeks of life.

questions.text: A child is admitted with DKA and is severely dehydrated. Their blood pressure is low and you would like to give them a fluid bolus. Their weight is 23kg. How much fluid should you prescribe in the bolus?
questions.solution:
Management of Diabetic Ketoacidosis is summarized as:

  • Fluid Type and Rate: Start with 9% normal saline (NS) or 0.45% saline for initial rehydration.
    Avoid rapid fluid administration: Rehydrate slowly over 48 hours to prevent cerebral edema, a serious complication in pediatric DKA.
    • Typical initial rate: 10-20 mL/kg over the first 1-2 hours, then adjust based on severity and dehydration.
  • Potassium Replacement
    • Monitor Potassium Levels: Children with DKA often have depleted potassium stores.
    • Start Potassium Replacement: Once urine output is confirmed and if serum potassium is below 5.5 mEq/L.
    • Typical regimen: Add potassium chloride or potassium phosphate to IV fluids, adjusting based on serum potassium levels.
  • Insulin Therapy
    • Start Insulin: Only after initial fluid resuscitation, usually 1-2 hours after IV fluids begin.
    • Insulin Dosage: Regular IV insulin at 05-0.1 units/kg/hour.
    • Goal: Gradually decrease blood glucose to avoid rapid shifts (aim for a drop of 50-100 mg/dL per hour).
    • Transition to subcutaneous insulin: When blood glucose approaches 200-250 mg/dL and ketosis/acidosis are resolving, switch to subcutaneous insulin.
  • Monitor Blood Glucose and Electrolytes
    • Frequent Monitoring: Blood glucose hourly; electrolytes, pH, and bicarbonate every 2-4 hours.
    • Avoid hypoglycemia: When blood glucose reaches 200-250 mg/dL, add dextrose (D5 or D10) to IV fluids.
  • Correct Acidosis
    • Avoid Bicarbonate Therapy: Routine use of bicarbonate is not recommended in pediatric DKA due to the risk of worsening cerebral edema.
    • Correction with Insulin: Insulin therapy, hydration, and electrolytes usually resolve acidosis.
  • Monitor for Complications
    • Cerebral Edema: Look out for signs like headache, altered mental status, and sudden bradycardia.
      • If suspected: Decrease IV fluids, elevate the head of the bed, and consider mannitol or hypertonic saline.
    • Electrolyte Imbalances: Watch for hypokalemia, hyperkalemia, and hypoglycemia.
  • Transition to Maintenance Therapy
    • Once the child is stable, acidosis has resolved, and able to eat, transition to a subcutaneous insulin regimen.

choices.text: Her diagnosis should be confirmed with an oral glucose tolerance test
She can be managed with oral hypoglycemic agents and dietary modification
She will have gained weight in the last few weeks

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl, is newly diagnosed with diabetes mellitus. She has been drinking lots of fluid and has had to pass urine frequently. She has a markedly raised blood glucose (20 mmol/L) and heavy glycosuria. Which of the following is most likely to be true about her diabetes?
questions.solution:
• Almost all (>95%) children have type 1 diabetes mellitus which occurs as a result of autoimmune destruction of pancreatic β-cells by T cells.
  • An oral glucose tolerance test is not required as her clinical presentation and investigations have established the diagnosis. The test is seldom required to diagnose diabetes in children, though it may be used to screen for cystic fibrosis related diabetes mellitus. (option a)
  • Oral hypoglycemics are rarely useful in Type 1 DM. She requires insulin. (option b)
  • Weight loss is a feature at presentation of Type 1 DM. (option c)

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with type 1 diabetes mellitus, is reviewed in the outpatient clinic. In spite of maintaining good control of his diabetes, his height has remained static for 9 months. He says his appetite is alright, but he has lost interest in sports. and he can't keep up with the other boys any more. He just stays at home and watches TV, but wants to be out playing football and getting back his energy. A full blood count and C-reactive protein are normal and his HbA1C is satisfactory. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Children with type 1 diabetes mellitus are at increased risk of thyroid disease and should be screened annually. His static height and his lethargy would support this diagnosis.
  • He is also at increased risk of coeliac disease and this should also be considered but is less likely as his appetite is good and his weight is satisfactory.
  • Eating disorders can co-exist with diabetes mellitus but he does not have the clinical features of anorexia nervosa. (Option a)
  • GH deficiency is not an autoimmune problem. Would not explain his lethargy. (Option b)
  • Blood and mucus in the stool would be expected with ulcerative colitis and anorexia and malaise and abnormal full blood count and C-reactive protein would be expected with Crohn's disease. (Option d)

choices.text: Oral rehydration, sodium supplements and oral glucocorticoid

questions.text: A 18-day-old female infant, has congenital adrenal hypoplasia. She presents having vomited all her feeds today. She has become lethargic and will no longer feed. On examination she has tachycardia, with a heart rate of 160 beats/min and a capillary refill time of 3 seconds. A bedside blood test shows that she is hypoglycemic. What is the best immediate management?
questions.solution:
• The child is having an adrenal crisis. This requires urgent treatment with intravenous saline, glucose and hydrocortisone. Long-term treatment is with glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid replacement and oral sodium chloride may be needed during infancy. The dose of glucocorticoid needs to be increased at times of illness.
  • The child is having a salt-losing crisis. Saline is needed along with glucose infusion. (option a)
  • This child is seriously ill. IV is preferred over Oral due to sickness of child. (option c, d)

choices.text: You are unable to tell if the baby is male or female, and tell the parents it is likely to be a mixture of both sexes, i.e. ovo-testicular disorder of sex development (DSD - or hermaphroditism).
You are unable to tell right now and a detailed assessment of the baby including scans and blood tests will be needed before a specialist can tell them
You are unable to tell right now but will be able to assign a sex as soon as you get the baby's chromosomes back
You think it is likely to be a girl so tell them the baby should be named as a female on the birth certificate pending the results

questions.text: A newborn baby has recently been delivered. The midwife requests an urgent pediatric review of the baby because she cannot tell if the baby is male or female. The parents are asking what sex their baby is. What should you tell them?
questions.solution:
• A detailed assessment by medical, surgical and psychological specialists needs to be performed followed by a full discussion with the parents before the infant is assigned a sex.
  • Sexuality is complex, and depends on more than the baby's phenotype, chromosomes and hormone levels.
  • If there is abnormal sexual differentiation at birth, do not guess the infant's gender. A detailed assessment needs to be performed.
  • Ovo-testicular DSD is extremely rare. It is usually possible to assign the infant a sex after assessment of phenotype, sex hormones and ultrasound scans of internal structures and gonads are performed.

questions.text: A baby is born with a disorder of sexual differentiation. Congenital adrenal hyperplasia is suspected. What blood result would confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Most children with congenital adrenal hyperplasia have 21-hydroxylase deficiency. The diagnosis is made by finding markedly raised levels of the metabolic precursor 17 α-hydroxy-progesterone.
    • Findings in 21hydroxylase deficiency can be summarized as:
      • Markedly elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone (17-OHP).
      • Low cortisol levels.
      • Elevated adrenal androgens (testosterone, androstenedione, DHEA).
      • Low aldosterone levels.
      • Elevated renin and angiotensin II due to hypovolemia.
      • Electrolyte abnormalities: Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and sometimes metabolic acidosis.
      • Elevated ACTH due to low cortisol levels.
      • Hyperpigmentation may be observed due to high ACTH and melanocyte-stimulating hormone
    • In congenital adrenal hyperplasia the testosterone would be raised. (option a)
    • In congenital adrenal hyperplasia the cortisol level would be low. (option b)
    • Glucose level would typically be low. (option c)
